awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Enzymes for Accelerated Plastic Recycling
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable a more efficient, profitable, and sustainable plastic recycling process. In the United States less than 10% of plastics are currently recycled, and the remainder are incinerated (15%) or placed in landfills (75%). Emissions from global plastics production and incineration could reach 56 billion tons of carbon between now and 2050, accounting for 15% of global greenhouse gas emissions. The economics of conventional plastic recycling are poor, because the high temperatures used in recycling cause quality degradation that greatly reduces the economic value.  This project develops a low-temperature system for high quality, high-value plastic products in closed-loop recycling.

The proposed project will apply synthetic biology and related biotechnologies to identify, engineer, and optimize new enzymes and enzyme cocktails to break down polyethylene (PE) and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastics.  These enzymes will enable closed-loop plastic recycling in an economically viable, low temperature, low CO2 emission process.   The first objective is to sample plastic contaminated environments for naturally occurring enzymes that have evolved to depolymerize PE and PET synthetic polymers.  Candidate PE and PET enzymes will be engineered to accelerate their ability to efficiently target and cut complex PE and PET polymers under scalable process conditions.  Millions of enzyme variants will be constructed, tested, and analyzed using synthetic biology, high-throughput screening, and machine learning technologies.  A primary goal of this effort is to demonstrate a 10-fold increase in PE and PET depolymerization rates compared to naturally occurring plastic degradation proteins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
New innovations for recycling of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic are needed to improve the volumes of high quality 100% recycled PET resin available for manufacture of high quality plastic products.  In this study, we performed an environmental survey of plastic-contaminated environments to identify novel microbes and microbiomes that break down PET plastic into chemical building blocks that can be used to re-manufacture PET plastic.  We performed genome and metagenome sequencing from microbial and microbiome samples, respectively, to enable bioinformatic identification of putative PET degradation enzymes.  We tested putative enzyme candidates by synthesizing their corresponding gene candidates and expressing them in E. coli to identify genes that enabled degradation of PET plastic.  After identification of several  enzymes responsible for break-down of PET (PETases), we chose the highest performing enzyme as a lead candidate to perform enzyme engineering and further improve enzyme properties.  

 

Our long-term goal is to achieve economical rates of enzyme-mediated plastic recycling, which will require significant PETase engineering in order to enable economical degradation of PET plastic under industrially scalable recycling conditions.  We developed protein engineering strategies to improve the rate of PET degradation, and were able to improve PET degradation by more than 10 fold under laboratory conditions. Improved enzyme performance was achieved in part by improving the thermotolerance of the lead enzyme candidate.   Commensurate with these discovery and protein engineering efforts, we developed a series of sensitive laboratory assays to detect and quantify the rate of enzyme-mediated PET plastic degradation over time.  These include microbe-based zone of clearing assays, purified protein assays, as well as assays that involved the use of droplet microfluidics to package cells with plastic particles and fluorescent reporter molecules that enable quantification of the rate of plastic degradation from the fluorescence properties of each droplet.  

 

These research efforts set a strong technical foundation for future enzyme protein engineering efforts that will drive iterative PETase performance improvements under industrially scalable conditions, and enable future commercialization of this technology. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Johan A Kers
por.por_txt_cntn:
New innovations for recycling of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic are needed to improve the volumes of high quality 100% recycled PET resin available for manufacture of high quality plastic products. In this study, we performed an environmental survey of plastic-contaminated environments to identify novel microbes and microbiomes that break down PET plastic into chemical building blocks that can be used to re-manufacture PET plastic. We performed genome and metagenome sequencing from microbial and microbiome samples, respectively, to enable bioinformatic identification of putative PET degradation enzymes. We tested putative enzyme candidates by synthesizing their corresponding gene candidates and expressing them in E. coli to identify genes that enabled degradation of PET plastic. After identification of several enzymes responsible for break-down of PET (PETases), we chose the highest performing enzyme as a lead candidate to perform enzyme engineering and further improve enzyme properties.

We developed protein engineering strategies to improve the rate of PET degradation, and were able to improve PET degradation by more than 10 fold under laboratory conditions. Commensurate with these discovery and protein engineering efforts, we developed a series of sensitive laboratory assays to detect and quantify the rate of enzyme-mediated PET plastic degradation over time. These include microbe-based zone of clearing assays, purified protein assays, as well as assays that involved the use of droplet microfluidics to package cells with plastic particles and fluorescent reporter molecules that enable quantification of the rate of plastic degradation from the fluorescence properties of each droplet.





These research efforts set a strong technical foundation for future enzyme protein engineering efforts that will drive iterative PETase performance improvements under industrially scalable conditions, and enable future commercialization of this technology.
